courses.name: Introducing Global Asia and its Histories

cmCourseInfo.description: This course introduces Global Asia Studies through studying historical and political perspectives on Asia. Students will learn how to critically analyze major historical texts and events to better understand important cultural, political, and social phenomena involving Asia and the world. They will engage in intensive reading and writing for humanities. Same as HISA06H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Introducing Global Asia and its Histories

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the close relationship between religions and cultures, and the role they play in shaping the worldviews, aesthetics, ethical norms, and other social ideals in Asian countries and societies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Asian Religions and Culture

courses.name: Global Buddhism in Historical and Contemporary Societies

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the global spread of different versions of Buddhism across historical and contemporary societies.
cmCourseInfo.title: Global Buddhism in Historical and Contemporary Societies

courses.name: Sub-Continental Histories: South Asia in the World

cmCourseInfo.description: A survey of South Asian history. The course explores diverse and exciting elements of this long history, such as politics, religion, trade, literature, and the arts, keeping in mind South Asia's global and diasporic connections. Same as HISB57H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Sub-Continental Histories: South Asia in the World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course provides an overview of the historical changes and continuities of the major cultural, economic, political, and social institutions and practices in modern Chinese history. Same as HISB58H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Modern Chinese History
cmCourseInfo.recommendedPreparation: 0.5 credit at the A-level in HIS or GAS courses

courses.name: West Asia and the Modern World

cmCourseInfo.description: For those who reside east of it, the Middle East is generally known as West Asia. By reframing the Middle East as West Asia, this course will explore the region’s modern social, cultural, and intellectual history as an outcome of vibrant exchange with non-European world regions like Asia. It will foreground how travel and the movement fundamentally shape modern ideas. Core themes of the course such as colonialism and decolonization, Arab nationalism, religion and identity, and feminist thought will be explored using primary sources (in translation). Knowledge of Arabic is not required. Same as HISB65H3
cmCourseInfo.title: West Asia and the Modern World

cmCourseInfo.description: This course examines the complex and dynamic interplay of media and politics in contemporary China, and the role of the government in this process. Same as MDSC40H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Chinese Media and Politics

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs.
Shortly after 3:00 pm on Thursday, July 14th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of the history of China's relationship with the rest of the world in the modern era. The readings focus on China's role in the global economy, politics, religious movements, transnational diasporas, scientific/technological exchanges, and cultural encounters and conflicts in the ages of empire and globalization. Same as HISC57H3
cmCourseInfo.title: China and the World
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 4.0 credits, including 0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS or HIS courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs. Shortly after 3:00pm on Thursday, July 14th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: The course will explore the history and career of a term: The Global South. The global south is not a specific place but expressive of a geopolitical relation. It is often used to describe areas or places that were remade by geopolitical inequality. How and when did this idea emerge? How did it circulate? How are the understandings of the global south kept in play? Our exploration of this term will open up a world of solidarity and circulation of ideas shaped by grass-roots social movements in different parts of the world Same as HISC73H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Making the Global South
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 4.0 credits, including 0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS or HIS courses

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs. Shortly after 3:00pm on Thursday, July 14th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.

courses.name: Senior Seminar: Topics in Global Asian Societies

cmCourseInfo.description: This course offers a capstone experience of issues which confront Asian and diasporic societies. Themes include gender, environment, human rights, equity, religion, politics, law, migration, labour, nationalism, post-colonialism, and new social movements. It is conducted in seminar format with emphasis on discussion, critical reading, and writing of research papers.
cmCourseInfo.title: Senior Seminar: Topics in Global Asian Societies
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 8.0 credits, including: [0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS courses] and [0.5 credit at the C-level in GAS courses]

courses.name: Aqueous History: Water-Stories for a Future

cmCourseInfo.description: This upper-level seminar will explore how water has shaped human experience. It will explore water landscapes, the representation of water in legal and political thought, slave narratives, and water management in urban development from the 16th century. Using case studies from South Asia and North America we will understand how affective, political and social relations to water bodies are made and remade over time. Same as HISD54H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Aqueous History: Water-Stories for a Future
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 8.0 credits, including: [0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS or HIS courses] and [0.5 credit at the C-level in GAS or HIS courses]

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs. Shortly after 3:00pm on Thursday, July 14th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.

cmCourseInfo.description: This course explores the transnational connections and contexts that shaped ideas in modern Asia such as secularism, modernity, and pan Asianism. Through the intensive study of secondary sources and primary sources in translation, the course will introduce Asian thought during the long nineteenth-century in relation to the social, political, cultural, and technological changes. Using the methods of studying transnational history the course will explore inter-Asian connections in the world of ideas and their relation to the new connectivity afforded by steamships and the printing press. We will also explore how this method can help understand the history of modern Asia as a region of intellectual ferment rather than a passive recipient of European modernity. Same as HISD55H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Transnational Asian Thought
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 8.0 credits, including: [0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS or HIS courses] and [0.5 credit at the C-level in GAS or HIS courses]

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs. Shortly after 3:00 pm on Thursday, July 14th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.

courses.name: Culture, Politics, and Society in Late Imperial China

cmCourseInfo.description: A study of major cultural trends, political practices, social customs, and economic developments in late imperial China (1400-1911) as well as their relevance to modern and contemporary China. Students will read the most recent literature and write a substantive research paper. Same as HISD58H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Culture, Politics, and Society in Late Imperial China
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 8.0 credits, including: [0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS or HIS courses] and [0.5 credit at the C-level in GAS or HIS courses]

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:

Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs.
Shortly after 3:00 pm on Thursday, July 14th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.

courses.name: Law and Society in Chinese History

cmCourseInfo.description: A seminar course on Chinese legal tradition and its role in shaping social, political, economic, and cultural developments, especially in late imperial and modern China. Topics include the foundations of legal culture, regulations on sexuality, women's property rights, crime fictions, private/state violence, laws of ethnicities, prison reforms and modernization. Same as HISD59H3
cmCourseInfo.title: Law and Society in Chinese History
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: Any 8.0 credits, including: [0.5 credit at the A- or B-level in GAS or HIS courses] and [0.5 credit at the C-level in GAS or HIS courses]

courses.name: Cuisine, Culture, and Societies Across Global Asia

cmCourseInfo.description: Examines the central place of cuisine to families, societies, and cultures across Global Asian societies and their diasporas, using tastes, culinary work techniques, community-based research, oral histories, digital humanities and multi-media experiential learning, as well as critical reading and writing.
cmCourseInfo.title: Cuisine, Culture, and Societies Across Global Asia
cmCourseInfo.prerequisitesText: 8.0 credits, including 1.0 credit from any program offered by the Department of Historical and Cultural Studies

notes.name: Course Note
notes.content:
Enrolment Control: P
Initially restricted to 3rd and 4th year students in the Global Asia Studies Specialist, Major and Minor Programs, and Food Studies Minor Programs. Shortly after 11:00am on Friday, July 15th, if there is no waitlist, any remaining space may open to other UTSC students with the prerequisites.
